bibl.title: Letter from H. Muench to H. H. Howard, December 4, 1923

div1.p: Muench summarizes data that he collected on yellow fever in the Guianas. He mentions the great ignorance or diffidence displayed by the sanitary authorities.

div1.head: Letter from H. Muench to H. H. Howard, December 4, 1923
div1.opener:
Copy
ANKYLOSTOMIASIS COMMISSION
Paramaribo-Surinam.
P.O.B. Box 349
St. Johns, Antigua,
Tuesday, 4.xii. 23
Dear Doctor Howard:
div1.p:
I am enclosing the various data on yellow fever in the Guianas
which I have been able to collect. In order to save time, I am giving
below a short resume of the main points brot out.
BRITISH GUIANA (Demerara):

Enclosed are papers, collected by Dr. J.F.C. Haslam, Medical
Officer of Health of Demerara. These are copies of the most important
replies received by him in answer to an inquiry sent out when it was
announced that a yellow fever committee would probably visit Demerara.

Two of these papers are by old inhabitants of the colony;
laymen. The other is from the oldest practising physician.

Apparently, yellow fever was not prevalent, or not recognized
to any extent before 1800 or thereabouts. From then on it seems to have
become increasingly common in Georgetown until the great fires in 1864,
after which it seems to have decreased somewhat. There seem to have been
epidemics in the 1880s and '90s, after which the disease gradually died
down, and, according to all available information, has not been heard of
since in the colony.
FRENCH GUIANA:

No papers are enclosed. I called on Dr. Blin, Surgeon General,
in Cayenne. In spite of the fact that I had announced my coming some weeks
previously, he knew nothing about it and had no data available. Besides,
he had only recently arrived in French Guiana, and was not familiar with
the past history to any great extent. He promised, however, to have all
data on old outbreaks collected and sent to me. So far, they have not
arrived.

According to Dr. Blin, yellow fever was endemic in the colony
until 1902. There would be outbreaks, from time to time, of “fievro bilieuse
inflammatoire”, which would gradually change into yellow fever. These out-
breaks usually followed the digging of ditches, graves, etc., in old ceme-
teries where yellow fever patients had been buried, sometimes a generation
before.

This “bilious inflammatory fever” would start somewhere farther
north; probably in the West Indies, and be carried down by way of Dutch
Guiana, by which time it would have been transformed into yellow fever.
1902, the year of the last outbreak, was a year of general yellow fever
epidemics all over the West Indies.

Since 1902, there has been no yellow fever in the colony; only
suspected cases of “bilious inflammatory fever”. However, within two months
before my visit (end of September, 1923) there had been two cases of undoubted
yellow fever on one of the Iles de Salut. One of the cases died and showed
typical lesions at autopsy. The other recovered, but ran a typical clinical
course.

This information is extremely interesting in that the Iles de Salut
are penitentiary islands along the coast (Devil's Island is one), with which
there is no communication except for an occasional boat from and to Cayenne.
Dr. Blin's explanation for the occurrence is that the convicts on this is-
land had just been digging in an old disused graveyard in which yellow fever
cases had in olden times been buried. The cases were the first in fifteen
years to be diagnosed as yellow fever.
DUTCH GUIANA:

Two copies of a translation of a report by Prof. Flu, on a yellow
fever epidemic in Surinam in 1908, are enclosed. This report, tho detailed
and long, is worth reading, as it was made by a trained epidemiologist who had
apparently been studying the question rather closely. Without going into
the report here, the main points are as follows:

Yellow fever, formerly prevalent, disappeared from the colony in
1866 and did not reappear until a deadly epidemic in 1902. It then was un-
heard-of until the epidemic described in the report, in 1908-09, which occurred
in a batch of new recruits just out of Holland. Since then, it has again
been unheard-of.

Flu stresses the point that there were a good many borderline cases
some time after the epidemic, and some quite a while before, which could very
well have been yellow fever; also, that the 1908 epidemic not only did not
attack those who had been thru the 1902 epidemic, but left alone all who had
been in the colony for longer than a year or so.

Aside from Flu's report, there was nothing to be found out. Appar-
ently, it comprised the sole yellow fever records in the Medical Inspector
General's office. In fact, it appeared to be news to the Medical Inspector
General that there had been another epidemic in 1902, and that there had been
yellow fever in the colony before 1866.
GENERAL SUMMARY:

The most striking point, when trying to collect yellow fever statis-
tics, is the great ignorance (or diffidence) exhibited by sanitary authorities
regarding the occurrence of the disease. Some appear to regard it almost as
treason to admit the occurrence of an epidemic which was known thruout the
world. I have even had denials that the epidemic in Surinam in 1902 was one
of yellow fever -- in spite of the 29 deaths.

Another striking point is the overlapping of dates. By this I
mean that one observer will note yellow fever during certain years, but
deny it in the interim; while another will cite other years of incidence.
For instance, Flu says that there was no yellow fever in Surinam from
1866 to 1902. Blin, however, says that yellow fever was constant in
French Guiana until 1902, kept alive by importations from Surinam. Thru
such overlapping dates, one acquires the suspicion that yellow fever may
have been pretty constant thruout over long periods of time, altho indi-
vidual medical observers may have seen none for years on end.

div1.p:
Finally, the point brot out by Flu, namely, the immunization
of a population to yellow fever without the (apparent) presence of the
fever, points to some sort of constant condition. Either a mild form of
the disease is continually present, as Flu suggests. This would explain
the immune population; also the two cases on the Iles de Salut, which
would otherwise be hard to explain without adopting the French graveyard
theory.

Or, there is some closely allied and prevalent disease which
gives immunity also to yellow fever. There is a sort of mild “dengue”
very common in Surinam, which might be an extremely mild yellow fever, or
a very similar disease; perhaps almost or quite as nearly related as vaccinia
is to variola. Some support of this theory could be found in recent work
done by some Dutch scientists in Java, who are isolating spirillae of the
“icteroides” type from a number of tropical fevers of different kinds, which
may thereby prove to bear some sort of relation to each other.

In any case, there seems to be little possibility of tracing any
course of yellow fever infection thru the Guianas. Yellow fever is supposed
to be extinct; whether it really is, or is lying dormant in a much attenuated
form awaiting the arrival of favorable conditions, including a large importa-
tion of non-immune population, is questionable. It will probably be impossi-
ble to answer the question until we have a definite and delicate means of
diagnosing extremely mild cases.

I am sorry that it seems impossible to get more definite information
along the lines the Board desired. In view of the fact, however, that officially
there is no yellow fever, and that there has been none for many years, it is
hard to trace down any course of infection.

If this report is of any use whatever to the Board, I shall be
greatly pleased.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, (Signed) H. Muench Dr. H. H. Howard,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, N.Y.C.
